image.altText: a middle-aged male police officer in uniform outdoors

props.synopsis: Lawyers allege several Aboriginal NT Police officers experienced racial vilification, derision and an unequal pay system on the job. The police commissioner says it's a "positive step" that they have the confidence to speak up.

title.children: NT police commissioner pledges 'reform', after Aboriginal officers lodge human rights complaint

image.altText: a grey industrial building in a darwin street

props.synopsis: A 32-year-old man who allegedly stole a car from a Darwin smash repairs shop at knifepoint has been arrested by Northern Territory police.

title.children: Man, 32, allegedly stole car at knifepoint from Darwin smash repairs shop

image.altText: Saline 1

props.synopsis: One senior clinician at a major Sydney hospital has described the ongoing situation as "a complete sh**show".

title.children: 'You're being asked to act as a gatekeeper': Doctors say they are still being forced to conserve IV fluids

image.altText: Anthony Albanese and Joe Biden shake hands, smiling.

props.synopsis: The leaders of Australia, the United States, India and Japan conclude their meetings in Delaware, announcing plans for joint coast guard operations in the Pacific and an expanded vaccination program.

title.children: China is 'testing us all' Biden tells leaders in hot mic moment, with Australia to join Quad allies for coast guard operations

image.altText: A woman with a neutral expression looks at the camera. In the background, medical equipment is visible.

props.synopsis: Sholbaana Kuular and her family have firsthand experience with regard to how racist Russian society can be, but a proposed new law that would limit the number of migrant children in classrooms has outlined how discrimination often starts at state level.

title.children: Inside the 'horrible machine' of Russian racism, where bullying starts at state level

image.altText: A man appearing tight lipped in front of a microphone.

props.synopsis: Tobacconists and convenience stores still selling illegal vapes almost three months after a nationwide ban came into force could soon face prosecution, as Health Minister Mark Butler signalled the need for a "far more assertive approach".

title.children: Health minister says a 'far more assertive' approach is needed to crack down on sale of illegal vapes

image.altText: A thumbnail composite of Wills Property's listing and complaints they received and their response.

props.synopsis: After a three-bedroom inner-Sydney apartment went viral for its strict conditions for tenants, the internet came hard for the agency behind it. In response, that same business has begun posting personal details of their critics in a move to stop the posts.

title.children: An unusual Sydney rental ad attracted critics online. Before long things blew 'out of all proportion'

image.altText: Photo illustration of logos for Google, Apple, Facebook and Amazon smart phone applications.

props.synopsis: It's useful to consider who the government may pit itself against as it tries to prevent disinformation spreading online, and stop younger Australians using social media.

title.children: The Albanese government could encounter powerful opponents in its fight against online disinformation

image.altText: A woman crouching down with an animal in a pouch, in the desert at dawn.

props.synopsis: A number of native animals, extinct in New South Wales for more than 100 years, are reclaiming the desert in Sturt National Park and scientists are trying to teach them how to survive predators like feral cats.

title.children: These native species were locally extinct but are now reclaiming their desert homeland

image.altText: Helen Housby and Amy Parmenter challenge for the ball.

props.synopsis: Dealt an injury blow before the game, the Roses spring an upset to beat the Diamonds 61-59 in a thrilling second Test in Sydney. Follow live.

title.children: Tenacious England pip world champions Australia in dramatic second Test to keep series alive

image.altText: The silhouette of a steel lattice gas tower at dusk with a flare at the top

props.synopsis: For half a century, Woodside has been the standard-bearer for Australian energy. But a weak share price and unpopularity have left it vulnerable to a US takeover, or move.

title.children: Languishing and vulnerable, Australia's oil and gas champion looms as tempting prey for America

image.altText: A drone shot of a 3D printed neighbourhood in Texas

props.synopsis: Texas just opened its biggest 3D-printed neighbourhood as a solution to its acute housing problem. Could it be the solution the Australian construction has been waiting for?

title.children: A 4-tonne machine just printed a house in the US. What can Australia learn?

image.altText: a group of men look at a BYD car in front of a BYD logo

props.synopsis: Despite tariffs and a slowing global demand for electric vehicles in recent months, China is steaming ahead with its transition to EVs.

title.children: 'The Chinese offensive is visible everywhere': The changing face of the auto industry

image.altText: A hand holding a phone displaying a map

props.synopsis: Since the start of the Gaza war, Israel has been deploying a tactic known as GPS "spoofing", which is designed to fool enemy missiles but has also had detrimental impacts on civilian life.

title.children: In the Middle East, dating apps, food delivery and map navigation are leading everyone to Beirut Airport

image.altText: Lady Elliot Island Silvereye on a plant

props.synopsis: Forest revegetation turns the Great Barrier Reef's southern-most island from a barren wasteland into a refuge for a new subspecies of silvereye birds.

title.children: These cheese-loving birds are fast-tracking evolution in island paradise

image.altText: A smiling man with brown hair and a bushy brown beard.

props.synopsis: Tributes are flowing for Alice Springs historian, teacher and family man Dick Kimber who died this week after a long illness, aged 85.

title.children: Central Australian historian Dick Kimber remembered as 'keeper of stories' after his death

image.altText: People preparing noodles and vegetables in a mobile kitchen.

props.synopsis: To service the huge demand for laksa at the famous food markets of Darwin, stallholders grind out long hours.

title.children: Laksa is Darwin's signature dish. This is how it gets made on market day

image.altText: A newspaper lies open with a story on one side headlined "Baby alone in murder house" and a picture of a boy.

props.synopsis: The case is said to have struck at the heart of Melbourne and 47 years later, it's yet to reach a conclusion.

title.children: The Easey Street killings became Victoria's most serious and longest running cold case, and it's not over yet

image.altText: Alison Donnan holds up a bit of Tupperware.

props.synopsis: Tupperware's plastic may be famously indestructible, but the US-based company filed for bankruptcy this week. It's cause for reflection from the Australians who sold the containers to party-goers across decades.

title.children: Tupperware's bankruptcy reflects an increasing skepticism around multi-level marketing schemes, experts say

image.altText: Bush at the proposed site of a hydrogen plant.

props.synopsis: It's the game-changing policy Labor didn't hold back on selling ahead of the 2022 SA election. But making a promise in opposition is one thing and actually delivering it in government is another, and the next three months loom as crucial for the hydrogen project's future.

title.children: Is a green hydrogen power play at risk of becoming a mirage in the scrub?

image.altText: Two men wearing suits. One is smiling and looking at the camera, the other has a hand to his chest

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Michel Barnier's government has a distinctly more conservative tilt than that of his predecessor Gabriel Attal.

title.children: France appoints new government in shift to right

image.altText: Linda Reynolds, John Barilaro and Bruce Lehrmann.

props.synopsis: The past 12 years have delivered a spectacular meteor shower of defamation cases brought by celebrities, politicians and businessfolk, and fought out on the national stage of the Federal Court. ABC Long Reads has the story of how it all began.

title.children: How a five-word phrase perfectly sums up the trap of defamation

image.altText: Danielle Ponter of the Crows celebrates a goal, hugging her teammates

props.synopsis: AFLW juggernaut Adelaide have extended their unbeaten start to the season, crushing Essendon by 33 points.

title.children: Crows take flight to sink Bombers by 33 points

image.altText: JessFox

props.synopsis: After her stunning success at the Paris Olympics, Jessica Fox claims the canoe World Cup title by the smallest of margins.

title.children: Jessica Fox adds canoe World Cup title to her growing trophy cabinet

image.altText: A person looks inside a building with rubble strewn throughout it

props.synopsis: It comes as the Lebanese health ministry raises the death toll from an Israeli strike on Beirut's suburbs to at least 37, including three children and seven women.

title.children: Gaza officials say at least 22 people killed in Israeli strike on school

image.altText: A man during election in Sri Lanka.

props.synopsis: Sri Lanka's Marxist-leaning leader, Anura Kumara Dissanayake, grabs a commanding early lead on Sunday in his bid to become the next president of the debt-ridden country seeking to elect a leader to bolster its fragile economic recovery.

title.children: Marxist politician Anura Kumara Dissanayake leads Sri Lanka's presidential vote

image.altText: a portrait of a man sitting at an outdoor table in his backyard

props.synopsis: Youth crime could decide next month's Queensland election. Thousands of victims are heading to the polls demanding change, but will locking kids up solve the problem in the long run?

title.children: Lee's wife was murdered by a teenager. He says the youth justice system needs to change

image.altText: Donny stares into the camera as he sits at the back of a bus wearing a yellow jacket, with antlers photoshopped behind him.

props.synopsis: The Emmy Award-winning show Baby Reindeer has brought stalking back into the zeitgeist. But what drives people to stalk others and how should their victims respond?

title.children: 'Any attention is fuel': The five types of stalker and how to stop them

image.altText: A close up of the preserved tree stump, just after it was unearthed from the sand, white beach and blue sky in background.

props.synopsis: Researchers and local Indigenous people say a beautifully preserved metre-wide and 40-centimetres-high tree stump may be a thousand-year-old messenger with a story to share about climate change.

title.children: Why this 7,000-year-old stump could unlock secrets about climate change

image.altText: The Menendez family and their grisly story gets the Ryan Murphy treatment

props.synopsis: American Horror Story creator Ryan Murphy is once again picking from the horrific crimes of the recent past to create his newest mini-series Monsters: The Lyle and Erik Menendez Story.

title.children: Lyle and Erik Menendez murdered their parents in the 1990s. Now Netflix is telling their story

image.altText: MrBeast

props.synopsis: A class action lawsuit filed against MrBeast, Amazon and others alleges mistreatment behind the scenes of the Beast Games TV show.

title.children: MrBeast promised them a chance at lifechanging prizes. The aftermath allegedly left them in therapy

image.altText: A video still of Tom Gleeson with his mouth and eyes open as he says 'HARD' on the set of Hard Quiz.

props.synopsis: You might not be on my show but that doesn't mean I'm going to make it easier for you.

title.children: Buckle up, it's time to test your trivia know-how, HARD!

image.altText: a bunch of red winegrapes hand from a vine

props.synopsis: Waste from suburban green bins is being reused as mulch on vineyards in central Victoria. Results have shown more vibrant grape growth and reduced chemical use.

title.children: Recycled mulch trial improving wine grape growth, reducing chemical use

image.altText: Close-up of a hand pulling a bottle of milk from the shelf in a supermarket.

props.synopsis: Food Standards Australia New Zealand research shows 22 per cent of us misunderstand best-before dates, and 33 per cent misunderstand use-by dates.

title.children: How long can you eat something past its 'best-before' date?
